verses.verse: The Song of Deborah (Ex 15.1) Then Deborah and Barak son of Abinoam sang on that day,
(Deut 32.43) “When locks are long in Israel, when the people offer themselves willingly (Meaning of Heb uncertain) — bless the LORD!
(Ps 27.6) Hear, O kings; give ear, O princes; to the LORD I will sing; I will make melody to the LORD, the God of Israel.
(Deut 33.2; Ps 68.7-9) LORD, when you went out from Seir, when you marched from the region of Edom, the earth trembled, and the heavens poured; the clouds indeed poured water.
(Ps 68.8; 97.5; Isa 64.1, 3) The mountains quaked before the LORD, the One of Sinai, before the LORD, the God of Israel.
(Judg 3.31; 4.17) In the days of Shamgar son of Anath, in the days of Jael, caravans ceased, and travelers kept to the byways.
The peasantry prospered in Israel; they grew fat on plunder, because (Or ceased in Israel, ceased until) you arose, Deborah, arose as a mother in Israel.
(Deut 32.17) When new gods were chosen, then war was in the gates. Was shield or spear to be seen among forty thousand in Israel?
My heart goes out to the commanders of Israel who offered themselves willingly among the people. Bless the LORD.
Sing of it, you who ride on white donkeys, you who sit on rich carpets, (Meaning of Heb uncertain) and you who walk by the way.

(1 Sam 12.7; Mic 6.5) To the sound of musicians (Meaning of Heb uncertain) at the watering places, there they repeat the triumphs of the LORD, the triumphs of his peasantry in Israel. Then down to the gates marched the people of the LORD.
(Ps 57.8; 68.18) Awake, awake, Deborah! Awake, awake, utter a song! Arise, Barak, lead away your captives, O son of Abinoam.
Then down marched the remnant of the nobles; the people of the LORD marched down for him (Gk mss: Heb me) against the mighty.

(Num 32.39; Judg 3.13, 27) From Ephraim they set out (Cn: Heb From Ephraim their root) into the valley, (Gk: Heb in Amalek) following you, Benjamin, with your kin; from Machir marched down the commanders, and from Zebulun those who bear the marshal’s staff;
(Judg 4.10) the chiefs of Issachar came with Deborah, and Issachar faithful to Barak; into the valley they rushed out at his heels. Among the clans of Reuben there were great searchings of heart.
(Num 32.1) Why did you tarry among the sheepfolds, to hear the piping for the flocks? Among the clans of Reuben there were great searchings of heart.
(Josh 13.24-28; 19.29, 46) Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan, and Dan, why did he abide with the ships? Asher sat still at the coast of the sea, settling down by his landings.
(Judg 4.6, 10) Zebulun is a people that scorned death; Naphtali, too, on the heights of the field.
(Josh 11.1, 2; Judg 1.27) The kings came; they fought; then fought the kings of Canaan, at Taanach, by the waters of Megiddo; they got no spoils of silver.
(Josh 10.11-14) The stars fought from heaven; from their courses they fought against Sisera.
(Judg 4.7) The torrent Kishon swept them away, the onrushing torrent, the torrent Kishon. March on, my soul, with might!
Then loud beat the horses’ hoofs with the galloping, galloping of his steeds.
Curse Meroz, says the angel of the LORD; curse bitterly its inhabitants, because they did not come to the help of the LORD, to the help of the LORD against the mighty.
(Judg 4.17, 19-21) Most blessed of women be Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, of tent-dwelling women most blessed.
(Judg 4.19) Water he asked, milk she gave; she brought him curds in a lordly bowl.
(Judg 4.21) She put her hand to the tent peg and her right hand to the workers’ mallet; she struck Sisera a blow; she crushed his head; she shattered and pierced his temple.
Between her feet he sank, he fell, he lay still; between her feet he sank, he fell; where he sank, there he fell dead.

(Prov 7.6) Out of the window she peered; the mother of Sisera gazed (Gk Compare Tg: Heb exclaimed) through the lattice: ‘Why is his chariot so long in coming? Why tarry the hoofbeats of his chariots?’
Her wisest ladies make answer; indeed, she answers the question herself:

(Ex 15.9) ‘Are they not finding and dividing the spoil? A woman or two for every man; spoil of dyed stuffs for Sisera, spoil of dyed stuffs embroidered, two pieces of dyed work embroidered for my neck as spoil?’
(Judg 3.11; Ps 19.4, 5; 68.2; 92.9) So perish all your enemies, O LORD! But may your friends be like the sun as it rises in its might.” And the land had rest forty years.
